title: How many deaths attributed to COVID-19 in the U.S. will be reported for the week starting 21 February 2021?
preds:
To reach 14k 2k per day needed on average. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-10-31..latest&country=CAN~EuropeanUnion~USA~FRA~GBR&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=daily&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc Day 1. 21/02 Sunday 1,249
Day 2. 22/02 Monday 1,413 total = 2,662
Day 3. 23/02 Tuesday 2,350 total = 5,012
Day 4. 24/02 Wednesday 3,230 =8,242
Day 5. 25/02 Thursday 2,417 total = 10,659
Day 6. 26/02 Friday
Day 7. 27/02 Saturday Why still sticking with bin 1?  If we have 2.5k on Friday then need exactly 2k on Saturday, but all Saturday reporting has been below 2k for weeks.

FWIW, total U.S. deaths reported at this source have increased by about 1900-2000 so far today (2/26) vs. around this time yesterday: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html Maintaining forecast but this one could be close between the first two (question) categories

Decreasing confidence in 14k to 16k a bit. A few things up in the air still. This readme file at the github repository linked below shows the 806 historical LA deaths. What remains to be seen is if those deaths get backdated before the data is accessed on March 6th. The readme lists some of the retrospective death reporting, but it looks like not all of them get backdated immediately. https://github.com/CSSEGISandData/COVID-19/tree/master/csse_covid_19_data#data-modification-records If they're not backdated before the numbers get pulled we're very likely to be between 14k and 16k. If they do get backdated it's a bit more of a tossup. The week prior, the remaining two days in the timeframe (Feb 19 and 20) had 2,689 and 1,821 deaths for a total of 4,510 deaths. If the 806 deaths get backdated, there would be 4,147 deaths remaining this week to stay under 14k deaths. So the 26th and 27th need to report about 8% less deaths than the same days last week. That seems doable, but hard to know if it'll happen. I'd guess the chances of the 806 deaths being backdated by the time the data gets accessed to resolve the question are pretty good. But I have no idea if the next two days to be reported can stay 8% below the previous week, and I would lean toward it being a little unlikely. Combining those factors, overall I think there's a little higher chance of landing between 14k and 16k deaths. Daily deaths chart: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-12-28..latest&country=~USA&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=daily&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=location&pickerSort=asc

At 10,659 as of yesterday. Our 7-day average has risen to 2,167. If we held that average, we'd break the 14K mark this week. I see that the crowd has moved significantly to the right on this prediction over the last 24 hours, and I'm tempted to as well given how high our peak was two days ago.  In taking a closer look at the numbers over the last 4 weeks, though, we can see that there is a fairly regular weekly "hump" in the data, with a peak followed by three days of increasing decline, then the nadir to begin the next week. Over the three weeks prior to last week, the day following the peak is lower, but not by a lot, which gives us the "hump" shape of the data each week. Yesterday, however, the drop was very steep...of course last week, this pattern shifted a bit and the day after the initial drop (the second day after the peak) actually went up. BUT! That was following a fairly minimal drop, much closer to the three weeks previous to it. So! Given yesterday's performance, I look for the numbers to drop significantly today and tomorrow as well. I'm not going all-in on the >14K number, but I admit that it's going to be very, very close.

Covid deaths seem to have gone into decline beginning in early February and now remain in the 1,000 to 3,000 a day range (according to the CDC). It continues to spike from the low 1,000 range to the low 3,000 range which is why I can't be sure whether it will be less or more than 14,000. However, there would have to be a higher number of deaths the next few days for the count to be over 14,000, so I am more inclined to choose fewer than 14,000.

Today's death will determine the forecast of tomorrow's
Will update once it becomes closer to closing date

To reach 14k 2k per day needed on average. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-10-31..latest&country=CAN~EuropeanUnion~USA~FRA~GBR&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=daily&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc Day 1. 21/02 Sunday 1,249
Day 2. 22/02 Monday 1,413 total = 2,662
Day 3. 23/02 Tuesday 2,350 total = 5,012
Day 4. 24/02 Wednesday 3,230 =8,242
Day 5. 25/02 Thursday 
Day 6. 26/02 Friday
Day 7. 27/02 Saturday Why sticking with bin 1?  Because Saturday is likely to see a lower number of cases reported and so average on Thursday and Friday have to stay high to offset.  Of course there could be 14,000 cases exactly in which case I should have spread the probabilities and done a proper forecast, but going to play this one as a gamble!

IF you google "covid deaths usa" it brings up an interactive graph using data from the NY Times.  That graph indicates the following:
Feb 21 - 1247 deaths
Feb 22 - 1454 deaths
Feb 23 - 2328 deaths
Feb 24 - 3210 deaths We are clearly in a new spike with total this week of 8,239.   If deaths exceeds 1920 a day for the next three days, the weekly total will be greater than 14,000.  So this is likely to be very close.   The trend might suggest we will easily pass 14000.  But you have to remember, there are regular spikes in the data.  The spikes tend to run between 4 and 6 days from trough to top.  We are at 4 days.  So the trend could head down soon. The expected Superbowl spike in cases does not appear to be happening, and case trends are still down. The safe bet would be 50/50 around 14000.  But I am leaning toward the high side.  Tomorrows data may provide a clear signal.

(Admitting that I can't find the exact data source this question uses (via the link in the text), I've been substituting another JHU CSSE source for reported U.S. COVID deaths: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html)  2/25/21 U.S. deaths reported by this source have increased again (so far today) by approximately 3,000 from the total I observed late yesterday. (U.S. deaths total reported (so far today, 2/25/21) by JHU = 507,803.)  By my current count nearly 10,800 new U.S. deaths have been added so far this week (starting 2/21), via the source above. FWIW this separate reporting source has essentially corroborated the week's numbers through 2/24/21: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/about-coronavirus-data-maps.html  ("New reported deaths/day") Adjusting the forecast (upward) to reflect significantly higher U.S. death tolls reported over the last three days. After 2/25/21 an average of something above (about) 1630 deaths/day (through 2/27/21) would appear to put the week's total above 14,000.

Yesterday's total was the highest we've seen in two weeks. However, as long as it follows the historical trend, it'll also be the highest we'll see this week. Still tight, and we're moving back in the wrong direction, but I remain optimistic.

After noting the significant increase in deaths (3,230) reported yesterday, I scrolled down to see who else already noticed this.  @Ryan-Beck (see below) did some research.  Today I don't have time to go deeper, so I'll move some beans to the second bin based on his work.  Thanks
Finding the data confusing, less sure of downward momentum.
Mixed influences - significant declines to about 2K/week but suspicions of new wave in some areas, though deaths will lag.

I looked at the data and found that the reason for the big jump to 3,230 deaths yesterday was because of a big increase from Los Angeles, and searching news from there it seems that Los Angeles just reviewed death certificates and added 806 deaths from prior months. Though even without the anomaly this week would still be up a little over last, so if John Hopkins correctly dates those deaths and the 806 deaths from yesterday get moved (like they did with a previous reporting dump), it still looks like the question is likely to end at over 14k deaths. LA death review: https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/coronavirus/southern-california-coronavirus/death-certificate-review-leads-to-806-more-covid-19-deaths-in-la-county-since-december/2535231/ I've seen some suggest that the winter storm may be the reason for the uptick in cases and deaths, meaning that some deaths from last week could have been reported this week instead. That would mean last week's drop was larger than it should have been and the increase this week compensated for it. Hard to say if that's true, but seems plausible. If that's true then the trend in deaths should start to go back down again soon since deaths haven't dropped as much as case counts have yet.
2447 deaths today, more than the same day in the previous week. So far it looks like the bump up this week may end up putting this week over 14k.

Per this JHU source U.S. COVID deaths 'spiked' up nearly 2,800 between the 2/23/21 and 2/24 report: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html Average deaths per day this week are now around 1,920/day per the (U.S.) numbers reported above. https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA

Welp, 21 FEB was indeed the first day in almost a month that we saw the 7-day rolling average begin to increase. We were already at ~5K deaths between 21 & 23 FEB, and the average daily deaths as of yesterday was about 2K and continuing to rise. I think it'll be tight, but (I hope maybe?) the trend may have been somewhat affected by the weather last week...

Weekly cases just exceeded 14k by a bit today, not sure why it's bumped up this week as the case lag should mean it should continue going down, but it's looking increasingly possible that the question resolves as 14k to 16k. Will depend on what the next couple days do, need to see less deaths than we saw on the 17th through the 20th to stay under.

The CDC projects that there will be around 17,000 deaths in the coming week (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#forecasting_weeklydeaths), and cases have been falling significantly, so I think it's likely that the number of deaths may be less than that.

To reach 14k 2k per day needed on average. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-10-31..latest&country=CAN~EuropeanUnion~USA~FRA~GBR&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=daily&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc Day 1. 21/02 Sunday 1,249
Day 2. 22/02 Monday 1,413
We’re already there and cases have been falling

Through basic graphing of the time series.  Global sums for each day are calculated, then sums by rolling week. 
Rate of variation (week over week) is computed (last at -18%).
This rate is supposed constant for the next days.  At the same time, this rate is smoothed (moving average) and residuals are computed.  Adding the worst residuals would not create a jump over the first bucket.
Hopefully just a data blip but weekly deaths have ticked up a bit in the last couple days.
To reach 14k 2k per day needed on average. Day 1. 21/02 Sunday 1,249

Considering significant improvement in detaining the spread of COVID-19 which directly impact the death rate, expectancy of the death rate is lower than 14,000.. But there's still a good possibility it could go between 14,000 - 16,000 with following factors : Ohio's late reporting issue, People start to lower their guard, and more people just die..

We had a huge drop early this week, but as with hospitalizations, it appears to have steadied back out in the last couple of days. It's still dropping, though, which is the key. We're already below 13K as of the 20th...Again, we could spike due to the variants or perhaps the opening up of public spaces, but I feel pretty good about sticking at *least* this low for the next week.

Last 3 days here https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~USA&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=daily&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc average over 2k per day.  Going to be close to 14k, just not sure which side. Upping forecast on bin 1 a bit.

Going into last week the rolling average is currently 3k per day, which would give 21k over a week according to CDC with a large drop off in last day or so to 2k per day.  7 day rolling average have a lag so more likely to be closer to 2k than 3k over next week.  https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailytrendsdeaths 2k per day being reported here and less than 14k reported in last 7 days. https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailytrendsdeaths Last 3 days here https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~USA&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=daily&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc average over 2k per day.  Going to be close to 14k, just not sure which side.
NYT is reporting about 1,800 deaths a day, barring shocking outbreaks or hospital failures I don't see the course of decreasing deaths changing.
Last 7 days just under 14k abut flattening.  Going for close to 50/50 bin 1 and 2.  But need to review again soon.
2/20 7 day moving average puts us at around 14490 per week.   Been a drop in both cases and hospitalizations.  So would expect deaths to drop more in next week.

1. The trend of deaths of each day is not a smooth line, it usually has a peak which might be the reason that it takes time to report death. 
2. The number of deaths is correspondent with the confirmed covid cases but is delayed because it takes time for the human body to fight against the virus. According to the covid cases reported by CDC and related reports, the delay is approximately 6-9 days. 
3. The confirmed cases is decreasing since January 14 and the recent 7-day average death is declining from 3114 on the 14th to 2124 on the 19th. The total deaths on the past 7 days lies on 14,868 which is close to 14,000. There's a huge change that it is gonna dropped off this line, but still a probability to keep upon the line because the confirmed cases is increased a bit in the last two days even the overall trend is declining hugely. 
4. the availability of hospitalization increased due to the lowered amount of cases, but the extreme winter weather condition made it harder for patient to get to the hospital.
Hospitalizations are way down, which should lead to continuing lower death rates.  See https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/covidview/index.html
15th Feb week shows significant reduction in death but taking into account late reporting (similar to Ohio Case), thus most probably between 14,000 - 16,000

Using "Cumulative confirmed COVID-19 deaths" U.S. graph numbers from this source (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA), based upon JHU CSSE numbers, reported U.S. deaths have been increasing again to a range of 2236-2558/day over the past three days through 2/19/21. Death numbers reported from the previous four days - back to 2/12/21 - averaged significantly lower. For now I'll go with the recent 7-day average calculated from the source above of about 1,885 deaths/day as a guesstimate for the (upcoming) seven-day forecast for this question. If the next few days report at/around the recent higher 2236-2558 number range a change will be needed.  (7 days X 1885 avg. deaths per day = an estimated 13,192 new deaths.)
Licking my wounds...have definitely been referring to a different dataset that I thought was closely equivalent but seems to trail meaningfully on reporting...

Since my last forecast 6 days ago: 
14,400 to 17,788 deaths (source: https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/weekly-covid-deaths?tab=chart&stackMode=absolute&time=2021-02-11..latest&country=~USA&region=World ) Crowd: 49% fewer than 14,000

Should have stuck with my guns, that spike in deaths (which has now seemed to have disappeared, maybe assigned to their correct dates now or something?) spooked me but seems we're following the decline in cases now and are at 14,400 weekly deaths. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-11-24..latest&country=~USA&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=weekly&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
Significant recent drop in reported U.S. deaths continues: https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/daily-covid-deaths-7-day?tab=chart&time=earliest..latest&country=~USA
Deaths at about 22k for week at Feb 7, but very steep downward slope since.
Deaths and hospitalizations continue to decline rapidly. No effect seen yet from Superbowl weekend or recent restaurants, bars and school openings in major cities

Since 3 weeks ago, the 7 days rolling total has been increasing decreasing at a sharper rate. 3 weeks ago, the 7 days rolling total was at 23k and decreases by less than 1% every day. For the last 9 rolling total was decreasing by 2% every day. In fact, we saw a big 8% decline from 15th Feb's rolling total to 16th Feb's rolling total.  I will not be surprised if we go under 14k in less than a week. if I have to be precise, I think the correct answer will be somewhere between 10k and 12k.

Covid deaths have been declining in the past weeks based on the CDC's covid death chart. Last week there were only around 7,000 deaths and the week before that, 11,000. With more people receiving the vaccine, the number of deaths will hopefully decrease.

Since my last forecast a week ago, the rate of decline has steadily risen (is that a double-negative?). Over the last 7 days, the weekly total has decreased between 2% and almost 4%. We were at 16.5K as of yesterday. We've seen *no* increases in over 2 weeks (since 1 FEB). If continued on a 3% decline through 28 FEB, we'd be looking at just over 11K for the week. If we should happen to level off, say to somewhere around 1%, we'd be looking at about 14.5K.  As with my forecast on hospitalizations, with another week of very rosy numbers to look at, I'm shifting to the left substantially. I'm not going to move it *all the way* left, because the increased incidence of new variants, for which we have less data re the efficacy of the vaccinations, tickle the back of my brain a bit. I'll temper my optimism, but I'm still pretty bullish.

COVID deaths are generally trending downwards, though they are still high. From Jan. 20 - Jan. 26, there were about 23,400 COVID-related deaths; from Jan. 27 - Feb. 2, there were about 21,600; from Feb. 3 - Feb. 9, there were about 21,200. If this trend continues, there will most likely be less than 20,000 US deaths.
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/forecasting-us.html

Current daily rate at 2400 per day and drop not yet slowing down.
If do next 7 days at this rate total will be 16,800 so setting this as my max figure.
7 days ago the av daily rate was 2,900 so if the rate drops again in the next 7 days at the same rate we would be about 1,900 per day or 13,300.
If the drop stalls at half way on 2,250 per day then this 15,750
Therefore most likely bin 2, with quite high prob of bin 1
Not forecasting events like super bowl to increase rate as hospitalisation and death usually lag cases and not sure there is time for this before end Feb

Significant drop over the past couple of days in new deaths reported in "Daily Trends in Number of COVID-19 Deaths in the United States Reported to CDC", after a previous 'spike'. (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailytrendsdeaths) Data is through 2/15/21 and may or may not be complete at this point. 
New deaths recently reported there (may have) dropped to around 1200-1300/day. This source also shows a very recent drop in "daily number of confirmed deaths" in the U.S. (7-day average): https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=IND~USA~GBR~CAN~DEU~FRA

All over the place on this one, really hard timeframe to analyse I have found.. looking at up-to-date data would probs help! Anyway, consecutive days of averaging circa 1k, no indication of any upsurge and vaccinations ... less than 14k looks highly likely now unless similar Ohio incident strikes again.

Now estimating 11,500-14,500 based on the steady and consistent drop in case numbers over the preceding weeks, and comparison with European countries than have had similar reductions and associated declines in death rates.
Considering Ohio late reporting, death might be lower

Week starting 8th Feb has 21,412 deaths
giving a strong signal that the trend is going sideways around 21,000 - 22,500
I don't see vaccine could mitigate the deadliness of the virus, especially in February. Fortunately, Biden has asked Americans to pay more attention to prevent the metastasis
Thus the range of death seems to fall on the lower end of the 20,000 - 22,500 range
Any other contradictive perspective? please tag me for discussion!
7-day averages are around 22k for recent weeks.
Have been sitting a bit low and need to pull average up on bins 4-5.  A bit surprised at how low the crowd is on those.

7 day average from here https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=USA~EuropeanUnion~GBR&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
Jumped back up over 3k per day, which is 21k.  Only a week to go so likely to be in that range.  To get less than 18k need less than 2.5k per day.  Which looked on the cards a week ago. Swinging to bin 4. Update 16 Feb, may have been reading the EU figures, not the US!

I agree with Ryan-Beck in expecting deaths to drop, relatively consistent with the sharp drop in cases since January 12.  Note that the number of deaths reported over the past week has been inflated by Ohio's late reporting of 4,000 "overlooked" deaths from the past several months.  This could happen again, of course, but if you take the seven-day average of 3,136 deaths, multiply it by 7 and deduct 4,000, you're at 17,952.  If deaths go down by only 22%, you're at 14,000.   Cases went down from January 12 to January 26 by 33%, and then by another 35% from January 26 to February 9--the slope has been pretty consistent.   I think the group is seriously underestimating the prospect that we wind up below 14,000 deaths for the week of February 21.

For reference the most-recent (2/13/21) CDC 7-day moving average for U.S. deaths was 3,136 per day. (I.e., remaining above 3,000/day.) This includes a 'spike' of 5500+ reported deaths on 2/12/21. (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailytrendscases) ..Keeping this forecast on the higher end unless the numbers reported above decline (e.g., below 3,000 deaths/day), soon.

The 7 day moving average is still around 2,500-3,000 (even though the case numbers are decreasing and vaccinations go fairly strong with 1,5-2 milion per day). Therefore I would focus my attention on Bin B-D but without leaving out Bin E.
Correcting previous mistake based on daily vs. weekly figures.

General expectation is that deaths should be decreasing in proportion to hospitalizations, but the numbers don't bear it out, over the last three weeks I'm seeing 22k, 22.5k and 22k.  With two weeks until resolution I'm expecting enough of an impact from vaccines to decrease the death rates into the 20k to 22k bin, but I'm ready to shift higher if the next few days don't show a marked decrease.  A lot of variability by day though, with peaks towards the end of the week.
Making prediction based on the understanding that this is for deaths for one week starting 21st.
downwards slope as more people get vaccinated

Readjusting after the recent spike. I was wrong about it being the start of the decline. Not sure why deaths haven't started following the trend in cases yet, seems like the lag is longer than I would have expected.
As the results this weekend show, these values can jump by ~1,000 pretty comfortably. That makes the final predection difficult.

As the day's uptick shows, this is a surprisingly noisy set of data. The huge spike will have to be removed from the weekly counts in a week though. 
Certainty is in short supply, but the downward trend should continue for now.

I generally agree with the thoughtful analysis by @Redcayenne . However, I think the effects of the vaccine are just too early to consider.  See this report about the effects of vaccination rates in Israel.  https://ourworldindata.org/vaccination-israel-impact.  There 40% have at least one dose and 25% are fully vaccinated.  New cases started dropping on Jan 15 when 25% had one dose (80% for those over 60) and 4% were fully vaccinated.  Even then, the drop was relatively modest. If you look at a chart of COVID deaths since the start of the year it looks like a weekly roller coaster bouncing between 1500 per day to 4500.  There is a slight downward trend over time.  Still there were 19486 deaths from 2/5-2/11.  The 7 day running total is shockingly consistent (see below for totals from 1/1 to 2/11) with the average change of + or - 384 (or 55 a day).  From 2/10 to 2/11 it was up 112.  The latest (2/11) 7 day total was 19468.  I expect this very slow decline to continue through 2/28.  The peak was 23549 on 1/14.  So we are currently down about 17% in one month and 14% in last 2 weeks.  17 days until the 28th, so with a 14% drop we would be at 16700.  But we could just as easily see things remain flat or increase slightly (due to new strains and Superbowl).  Over 20k seems less likely and under 16k seems excessively optimistic. 17615

Between Jan 22 and Feb 1st the USA added 29,268 to the death toll.
Between Feb 1st and Feb 11th the USA added 30,631 to the death toll.
https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=USA~GBR~CAN~DEU~FRA Although it appears that the number of new hospitalization is falling by roughly 20%, the death toll is increasing at regular rate.  However, deaths are a laggard, so hopefully this will begin to see the effects of increased vaccinations, double masking, better compliance with preventative measures.   USA Deaths for 10 day periods:
Jan 1-11 = 28,492  (= 19,944 for 7 days)
Jan 11-21 = 34,103 (= 23,872 for 7 days)
Jan 21-31 = 31,009 (= 21,706 for 7 days)
Jan 31- Feb 10= 28,797 (= 20,158 for 7 days)
https://ourworldindata.org/ People who are dying now got the virus roughly a month ago.  And the fatality rate sits stubbornly at 1.7%.  The period between 1/21 and 1/31 saw an increase of 1.53 million cases.  On a weekly rate that comes to 1,070,300 per week.  Applying the 1.7% fatality rate we would come to 18,195 if deaths lag cases by one month.  (The CDC has stated previously that it can range from 2 weeks to 8 weeks after the onset of symptoms.)   However, data is showing that vaccines prevent serious cases of Covid.  The vaccinated may get it, but the chance that they will die is greatly reduced.  As of now 14% of the population is vaccinated.  A month ago that number sat at 5.3%.  If we reduce the 18,195 by 5% we get 17,725.   I'm leaning primarily into the 18,000 - 20,000 (mostly because I am a pessimist by nature, and there WAS the super bowl super spreader event that will increase cases these next 2 weeks).  However, I'm hoping we will see the fatality rate fall as the vaccines prevent serious cases, yet I think it might be a bit early to see those effects if the lag in deaths is more than one month after onset of symptoms. So I'm hovering around tha 18,000 mark in my forecast.  Splitting on either side of that with a little sloping on the shoulders.  I can see I'm a bit more pessimistic than the crowd, but it just seems that the fatality rate is not responding as well as the case rate and we have a couple more weeks to go to see those effects.  Will definitely revisit this next weekend!

Since my last forecast 6 days ago:
21,344 to 19,410 daily death No evidence in favour of a drastic decrease or increase in the number of deaths. Rather, we are moving towards a decrease in view of the current decrease in the number of cases.  Initially I wanted to answer 0/0/1/80/18/1/0 but the Crowd say 12/35/35/17/1/0/0 so I edit my forecast
In good news for the US, I seem to have been very wrong early on.

I'm feeling pretty confident the drop over the last few days is the lag between cases and deaths catching up and that we'll see a steep drop in deaths over the next few weeks like we have for cases. 37% drop in weekly cases from Jan. 14 through Jan. 21, which is about how much time until the resolution of this question. If the same drop were to occur in weekly deaths from today it would drop from around 19,500 deaths in the past week to 12,300 deaths in the past week. That said, deaths may not behave the same way that cases did and the recent drop in cases could be concentrated among lower risk groups so I'm not going all in on below 14k. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~USA&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=weekly&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc

CDC's "Observed and forecasted weekly COVID-19 deaths in the United States" model now forecasting around 17,542 deaths about two weeks from now. (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#forecasting_weeklydeaths) "Daily confirmed COVID-19 deaths, rolling 7-day average" for the U.S. has recently dropped below 3,000/day: https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/daily-covid-deaths-7-day?tab=chart&time=earliest..latest&country=~USA
Deaths will increase as more data is processed. There is a current backlog on reporting COVID deaths.

This one is proving tricky. 4 days of significantly fewer deaths than the prevous week have contributed to a large drop in number. While that is a small number of days, the peak has definitely been passed so we are on the downslope here. We are already at ~20,000 deaths in a week by my count.

Based on a 14+ day lag in deaths following confirmed cases, the deaths during the week starting on Feb 21st will correspond to 1.5-1.7% of confirmed cases from the week 7-13 Feb. Confirmed cases from 7th to 9th is 117276 + 110853 + 108128. Assuming roughly the same trajectory, the remaining 4 days would total 335k confirmed cases. All of these combined gives 670k cases.  1.7% of this number gives 11.4k deaths.  However, considering deaths from the 2nd of Feb to the 9th of feb totalled almost exactly 21k, this seems quite low. The reduction in daily deaths from the 2nd to the 9th is only 232. Perhaps a better approach is to assume the same weekly reduction in the weeks to come, which would yield approximately 16-17k deaths for the week starting 21st Feb.  Considering the vaccine rollout, reduced stress on health services as a result of decreasing numbers, I would assume the number will be less than this, probably between 14-16k.
Reductions in positives through January suggests a resulting drop in deaths in the next few weeks

It appears that we haven't seen the same drop in deaths that we've seen in hospitalizations, or at least the change is not as dramatic. According to https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=IND~USA~GBR~CAN~DEU~FRA we've been looking at about 21K-23K deaths per week (rolling) for the last couple of weeks. That puts my base rate between 21K & 23K. I haven't taken a close look at this data before, so I'd like to dig deeper re why the deaths don't appear to have dropped at the same rate as hospitalizations...I have a hunch there's something I'm missing. In any case, I'd expect death rate to drop as the vaccines get moving. On the other hand, there is increasing rumbling about the vaccines being less effective against some of the new variants (though I think even in those cases, they're less effective *overall* but may be at least somewhat effective at preventing the worst, i.e. death).
The 7 day average is still hovering around 3,300 but big drop posted today at 1,479 (could be an issue with data processing over the weekend)

No update to my forecast, but I did confirm that the reference timeseries matches the data used at Our World in Data. Using John Hopkins data to find the weekly numbers in this google sheet: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1owKaBMF7RrJSVj8g6ZSWzhFuB6py_sr6sR-iCJ-jMTE/edit?usp=sharing Confirmed it matches the timeseries shown here: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~USA&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=weekly&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc Just a heads up for anyone else who was wondering if using another data source would match the John Hopkins data. Also if you switch to the new per day category at the Our World in Data link it looks like yesterday was the first day to show a drop in deaths compared to recent weeks, so I think we're now at the point where the deaths lag will start to match the drop in cases, so I would expect we'll see a drastic drop in deaths over the coming couple weeks. If we don't start to see deaths dropping quickly over the next week I'll have to adjust my forecast.

I'd made an error on my maths. At least it has reduced the noise in the distribution. The numbers are high, but there has been a large drop in cases in the US for a while now, so one shouldn't see the deaths rise to over  24,000.

With new virus variants circulating, it may be possible that Super Bowl gatherings could have a measurable negative effect upon new (U.S.) COVID case numbers in the weeks ahead, and - eventually - new deaths. (I.e., similar to holiday gatherings.)   Given this question's time period such an effect may be more pronounced in the number of new cases, vs. deaths. https://apnews.com/article/us-news-pandemics-coronavirus-pandemic-infectious-diseases-california-3dcd7ecda72b30501220ae9c2d2e40ee

Customizable charts at this source appear to use JHU CSSE COVID-19 data: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/united-states?country=~USA Per that source the U.S. 'daily confirmed COVID-19 deaths, rolling 7-day average' has stayed in approximately a 2,997 to 3,354 deaths/day range since 1/8/21, through 2/2/21. The graph's most recent 'trajectory' since a peak on 1/26/21 is downward, approaching a 3000 deaths/day average. The CDC's current "Observed and forecasted weekly COVID-19 deaths in the United States" shows a significant decline in forecasted U.S. fatalities over about the next four weeks, from an actual (weekly) total of about 22,000 deaths/week down to about 18,000 deaths/week in around three weeks and roughly 17,000 fatalities/week forecasted in four weeks: https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#forecasting_weeklydeaths I'll continue to watch these and other sources and will start this forecast with a 'guesstimate' more or less in the area of the CDC's three-weeks-out forecast of about 18,000 U.S. deaths/week.
